We have to ask ourselves what would happen if the Liberals got into power, especially now that the new ideologues control the Liberal Party. For one thing, we can look overseas at some of their idols. We can look how well things are running in Britain under Margaret Thatcher who has taken on the unions time and again. There is lousy economic growth, high unemployment, a high inflation rate and, in spite of North Sea oil the country is going down the drain under Thatcherism, or the so-called dry philosophy that we hear of from time to time. The Liberals argue that if they are put back in power they will deregulate the labour market and allow the law of the jungle to take over. The Liberals are saying that militant or strong unions can do what they like. The Liberals are prepared to let those employees covered by weak or ineffective unions go down the plug hole and to let their standard of living drop in order to support profit levels or something else.

If honourable senators opposite want to criticise a Labor government and its handling of industrial relations they have to come into the chamber and show that they can do better. There are two reasons why they will not-their quoted past record and their future proposals. Those future proposals in terms of industrial relations are an absolute disaster. I suggest that instead of sitting in this place maybe we should be generous, pair a few more liberals and send them to the Australian Council of Trade Unions congress so that they can meet some trade unionists and understand what their problems are and how they will deal with them now and into the future. But no, the Liberal Party prefers to use as scapegoats the union movement to blame for its own inadequacies.

Senator Short raised a few matters. He said that two of the unionists involved happened to be prominent members of the Left. I also notice that the main adversary, Mr Mulcahy, who runs for the employers, founded the Socialist Left in Tasmania in 1972. It may be a case of old extremists falling out. I have never supported any of the people who were mentioned, employer or employee. Senator Short alleged that there have been bomb threats, a fire and intimidation and that telephone lines have been cut. He raised all those issues. That would never be a proper industrial tactic that we on this side would support. In no way could this Government ever support those activities if indeed those on the picket line were charged. He mentioned only one set of charges and, for obvious reasons, I should not explore them. But if it can be proved that people on the picket line were guilty of those offences, we as a government will condemn them and they will go the normal legal processes. There is no way that, in the honourable senator's view, the much despised Cain Government would not proceed on that matter. We have shown, and the Cain Government has shown, a fair deal of courage when there has been law breaking in the industrial area to take on those particular groups.

Senator Short referred to his adjournment speech in which he criticised some of the officials for their overseas trips. The only thing I ever find in common with these people and the extreme conservatives who sometimes exist opposite is that they all like a trip. They just go to different spots. Some of these people may go to North Korea or Libya. I do not find that particularly offensive. Some honourable senators on Senator Short's side of the House go to South Africa and to every other right wing dictatorship in the world. The general Liberal Party on the extreme right has a lot in common with these people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support the Libyan Government?

—Not at all. If I had to wait to be offered a trip to Libya by the Libyan Government, I would have to wait a long time. I would even have to wait longer than the time when Senator Short and his colleagues get back in government. In summing up, this dispute goes to compulsory conference next Friday in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. One would hope that it can be settled there. It has never been the Australian Labor Party's view that just sacking employees in the middle of an industrial dispute will solve anything. I have never known that to occur, and it never will. The Government's attitude is that it will not support claims outside the normal guidelines. That has been indicated by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. Further, it was indicated by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in a telex to the Dollar Sweets company and to the union that there will be no support in those circumstances.
—What have you done about it?

—I am asked what we have done about it. Are we supposed to solve every industrial dispute in this country? What a ridiculous proposition, especially considering the Liberal Party's record. The only record the Liberals hold is in stirring up industrial disputes, never in settling them. The matter is in hand and one hopes that it will be resolved. What we have done in this country in creating the accord, reducing working days lost by 300 per cent and developing economic growth is establish a far more viable industrial relations atmosphere.

SPEECH.PARA: We have one more step to go in this industrial area, in my view, and that is in considering the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems to bring about more and more reforms in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. When that is done, there will be a very harmonious atmosphere in this country. One will never stop one or two unions jumping the gun, but we as a government have indicated that we will not support them. We have not supported the Food Preservers Union on every occasion. That does not mean we should set out to destroy it or anything else, but we shall not support unions on every occasion. If Senator Short and others do not see this matter of urgency as a union bash, too many people, given the Liberals' past history as a party, will consider it so. That is a most unfortunate attitude, and I await just once in my lifetime to hear one Liberal come out and support one industrial dispute. I could be proved wrong because as a 12-year old I remember thinking: `Just for once I wonder what would happen if the Herald editorial came out and suported the Labor Party'. Two things happened. We only squeaked in and Opposition members squealed like stuck pigs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of the great eloquence of my friend Senator Robert Ray, I would point out that he has failed to established the case that the dispute at Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd is just another industrial dispute. It is in fact a very special industrial dispute. It is an example of a rebel union, in this case the Federated Confectioners Association of Australia, using industrial muscle and intimidation against small business to make gains outside the prices and incomes accord. For that reason I have very much pleasure in supporting Senator Short's motion that the Government take urgent action to resolve this dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the accord was signed, this union, the FCA, managed to squeeze a 36-hour week out of the larger employers in the confectionery industry in Australia. It did so by using lightning strikes, and the workers walked out on machinery that was involved in continous production processing. They walked out when the machinery was still running and caused great damage and expense to the firms concerned. It was largely as result of these underhand tactics by the FCA that the confectionery industry today is largely foreign owned. The activities of this union so undermined the profitability of the larger confectionery manufacturers that they had no option but to sell out to overseas bidders. If this union manages to bankrupt smaller producers in Australia as well, the industry will virtually be totally foreign owned. This would be a tragic state of affairs for this country.

The Confectioners Association and the Food Preservers Union were the only unions that did not sign the accord in 1983. That is significant. It meant that their members were not entitled to indexation wage rises, and so members of those unions were disadvantaged. To overcome the problem the employers in the confectionery industry negotiated with the workers a de facto accord which gave the members of the union indexation and prevented them going for pay rises outside the accord guidelines. Eventually, the FCA was forced to sign the accord because all its members were working under it anyway in a de facto sense.

Early this year the union issued Dollar Sweets with a demand for a 36-hour week. This claim was both outside the wage indexation guidelines and ran contrary to the agreement signed by the workers with the management of the company concerned, Dollar Sweets. In fact, Dollar Sweets employees were already working a 38-hour week when the award specified a 40-hour week. The larger employer producers of confectionery in Australia were as a result of previous activity by this union working a 36-hour week. But the owner of Dollar Sweets said: `I am sorry, but I cannot afford to work a 36-hour week. We are working a 38-hour week and we should be working under the award of 40-hour week. My financial position is such that I cannot afford to finance a 36-hour week'. He offered to show the union the books of accounts setting out the company's position. The union refused even to look at them. It said: `Give us a 36-hour week or else'. The picket lines that were set up, as we have heard from Senator Short, have resulted in violence and intimidation. Telephone and telex lines have been cut. Telecom Australia has refused to fix these lines because a picket is in place. The net effect, as we heard yesterday, is that incoming calls to Dollar Sweets have ceased.

The important point, I believe, is this: If Dollar Sweets had given in to the demands for a 36-hour week it inevitably would have spread to all small manufacturers of confectionery in this country. Dollar Sweets cannot afford a 36-hour week and it is very likely that most other small manufacturers of confectionery in this country could not afford it either. Essentially, Dollar Sweets has been placed in the position of holding the line for what remains of the industry that is owned by Australian investors of capital.

The dispute is a perfect example of a militant union trying to pick off small business by isolating it and applying great pressure. Dollar Sweets is to be commended for withstanding the pressure so far. Union tactics in this case have not worked, and only because of the strength of the management. Next time things could well be different. It is essential that the Government take note of this dispute. It has serious ramifications. It is not just another industrial dispute. It is a dispute that involves small business and unfair tactics by militant unions against small business. If the Government does not take note of this and do something to protect the interests of small business people-entrepreneurs who are struggling to make a profit, notwithstanding unfair tactics by unions-the future of small business in this country will be very bleak.

I do not believe that it is up to us to say what action the Government should take. I think the case has been established that so far the Government has taken virtually no action. Senator Robert Ray tried to establish that the Government should not interfere in each isolated industrial dispute. This is not an isolated industrial dispute. It is a dispute directed at small business. Small business needs some sort of special protection. It is not getting it at the moment. It is not receiving protection against the actions of militant rogue unions such as the Federated Confectioners Association. The Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law took up this issue to some degree. It suggested that it was necessary for some sort of sanctions to be applied to keep unions in line. There must be some better method than we have at the moment of ensuring that unions are not using underhand, unfair and unlawful tactics in industrial disputes. The suggestion that Hancock mentioned was that there should be easier provisions for deregistration of militant unions. That may be one action that Government could take.

The fact is that small businesses are vulner able to being picked off one at a time by the actions of large and powerful unions. That is a fundamental issue that the Government should consider. It cannot rest on its record and say: `We have had no, or very little, industrial disputation in this country since the Labor Party came to office'. That may be true. But it is also true that unions such as the Builders Labourers Federation and the Federated Confectioners Association are using tactics that will have very serious repercussions if they are not stopped. The Government has not come forward with any constructive suggestion as to how these unfair and underhand tactics can be policed and brought to an end.

Small business is the area to which the Government must look if it is to solve the unemployment problem in Australia. It is very significant that in the United States the nine million jobs that were created to lift that country out of recession were created by small business enterpreneurs establishing new enterprises. In fact, large business has been responsible for a net lowering of employment in the United States. The same thing undoubtedly will happen in this country. The Government must look at the problems facing small business, such as the problems of attacks by militant unions, the problems of financing, and the problems of on-costs, such as workers' compensation, payroll tax and superannuation. I suggest that these problems, these burdens which are placed on small business, are critically important in the sense that we must solve the unemployment problem quickly and we must look to small business to do that for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of urgency that is before the Senate reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The actions of those militant unionists whose defiance of decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission may force the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd into closing its operations in Australia, and the necessity for the Government to take urgent action to have the dispute resolved.

It would seem from what has been said so far by honourable senators opposite that in some way the Commonwealth Government should take police action and that it should direct the police-those people who traditionally have been independent of government-to take action in a particular situation. Presupposing that there is the lawlessness that the Opposition talks about, why does it say that that lawlessness, if it exists, should be answered by an equally unlawful act, namely, by the Government entering into the affairs of the police force an independent body and directing it to do things which are not in accordance with the way in which it would want to do things? The day a government-whether it be a State government or the Commonwealth Government-starts to direct the police forces of this nation in what they do, it will be time for us to become quite concerned about the matter.

The supposed lawlessness that has been talked about has been talked about in language which is quite inflammatory. I am absolutely sure that this was not the intention, but that language has been the tendency to raise hatred and contempt of particular people. That is perhaps unfortunate when, as Senator Short said, the case will be hearded before the Prahran Magistrates Court on 19 September 1985. No good will be done in terms of industrial relations in this country by stirring up, as it were, sentiments of disgust, ridicule or hatred against those involved on one side of a dispute.

Senator Siddons stated that the difficulty was that small business was involved. He said that small business should not be subject to the effects of unionism. That is a debate that no doubt will take place in the months ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say who was being discriminated against?

—He said that where small business was concerned unionism in effect should not exist. That is not perhaps a matter for debate now. However, it is certainly an issue which he has brought up. It indicates that there are concepts which will fundamentally change the way society has existed until now-for example, the areas in which unions have had to operate, and the way the police operate. The matter which has been raised here is quite revolutionary.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point is this: An attack has been made on the union. To be fair, I should say that this is a union for which I have acted. Instead of making statements I shall read from an article in the Age dated Saturday, 7 September 1985. On page 5, under the authorship of a David Trounce, it is stated:

The stalemate has been worsened by the hardliners on both sides, in both cases no longer the people directly involved. The once tame confectioners association has been transformed over a decade into a militant left-wing union closely tied to the Food Preservers Union. The confectioners association was the last to sign the national wage guidelines, the FPU-
the Food Preservers Union of Australia-
the second-last. Both unions have little credibility in the ACTU.
The once troubled-free Dollar Sweets factory is represented by an equally intransigent employer group, the Confectionery Manufacturers Association Ltd, answerable to no one.

It is headed by an ambitious business lobbyist, Mr Richard Mulcahy, who is out to impress his member manufacturers so they do not defect to rival employer organisations, as many of the bigger multinationals have done.

Honourable senators may think that that is a statement by a fair-minded journalist. What he is saying is: Yes, perhaps there is a hard-line reaction from the union but there is equally a hard-line reaction from the employer. Where are we going to get if, when again and again we debate disputes in this chamber, we extrapolate from them one side and cast upon it all the opprobrium, all the hatred and all the abuse and leave out the other side? How can we get parties to negotiate? How can we do something if we in this Parliament continue to pick out one side of industrial disputes criticise it and ask it to do all that-

TALK.START.PARA: —What should they do-give in on the 36-hour claim?
—Senator Lewis asks whether they should give in on the 36-hour claim.
—That is what you are arguing.

—I am not arguing that. I think that is a fair point: Should the employers give in on a 36-hour week? However, that is not what the dispute is now about. The dispute certainly began over a 36-hour week. There is no doubt about that. That came from the negotiations that took place in 1982. At that time discussions were held between the Confectionery Manufacturers Association Ltd, which represented Dollar Sweets, and the union. Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd, through the Confectionery Manufacturers Association, offered its employers a 36-hour week. It must be remembered in this context that 90 per cent of the members of this union work a 36-hour week. However, those people who worked for Dollar Sweets-I do not want to make a judgment at this stage; this is just factual material on the background of the dispute-work 38 hours a week whereas most of their fellow unionists, 90 per cent at least, work a 36-hour week.

SPEECH.PARA: To put it fairly, the agreement that Dollar Sweets introduce a 36-hour week in June 1983 was part of a wider agreement between the two bodies and the Confectionery Association did not accept it. Nevertheless, the employees at Dollar Sweets expected to get a 36-hour week. Opposition senators have said that that is against the accord guidelines and so it may be, but that expectation was there. Employees at that factory had a secret ballot. They directed the executive of the union to take up the question of a 36-hour week with Dollar Sweets which then directed the union to the Confectionery Manufacturers Association. That body refused to negotiate. Following that, strikes occurred and Dollar Sweets demanded that the employees sign an agreement not to take industrial action. Senator Short has pointed this out. They went on strike in respect of the undertaking that they do not undertake industrial action. They were then dismissed. The dispute reached the point where the union said that it wanted to discuss the re-engagement of the sacked people. At that stage the 36-hour week issue was no longer an issue. That is what the dispute is about; it is about re-employing the people who have been sacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just a slide, isn't it?

—There is no doubt that it comes from the original dispute. But the dispute now in existence is about rehiring the sacked people. I think Senator Siddons or Senator Short pointed out that the union called a compulsory conference. It was called at the insistence of the union. I am not saying that the union is completely free of blame. What I am saying is that Dollar Sweets should not be elevated, particularly in terms of its representation through Mr Mulcahy, as a pure white knight in shining armour. To get a settlement to this dispute-it must be settled somewhere along the line-the need for discussion is paramount and it needs to be recognised that both sides have sins which have to be forgiven before we go any further.

SPEECH.PARA: It will not get us anywhere to say that police offences have been committed. What has that to do with the matter if the police are investigating it? As Senator Short has said, the police are investigating the matter. At this stage it would be wrong for anybody to suggest that the confectioners union, or any part of it, is to blame for any of the alleged acts of violence because that is very much a police matter. We in this Parliament should not prejudge any issues which may later go to court. I think that is a fundamental principle which is absolutely essential to keep in mind. As parliamentarians, we should not try to usurp the proper function of the policing authorities of this country. Senator Short asked the Minister for Police and Emergency Services in Victoria, Mr Mathews, why he had not done something about the matter. Mr Mathews is not in a position to direct police to take particular action in respect of alleged offences. That is a misconception of the way the police force operates. To suggest in the Parliament that that situation ought in some way to be changed has the following difficulties: Firstly, it is a State matter and, secondly, it involves a policy which has been pursued for many years, not only here but in England and elsewhere that the police should be kept above politics and away from the control of politicians. It has been said that the Federal Government should do something. It is all right to do something, but what should be done? Senator Siddons got over that point by saying: `I do not really know what the Government ought to do'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You claim some sort of a special relationship with the union movement. Why don't you exercise that?
—The special relationship with the union movement has worked very well, as the accord has shown.
—Only with those who are prepared to take the pay rises.

—With great respect, we cannot extrapolate one or two instances and make them the basis for a general proposition. We have to ask, when we look at all the evidence: What is the preponderance of the results? The results show that this Government has done very well indeed over the last few years in terms of industrial relations. All I say-I am sure that Senator Lewis is the sort of man to take this up-is that we have to understand that there are two sides to a dispute. The way to work through a dispute is first of all to accept that fact and to get to a compulsory conference, as the union has done in this case, and see what comes of that. If we say `This is going to set a new trend, a new precedent, it is all hopeless', if we throw our hands in the air and say `Oh, Oh', where will we get?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons said that this is an extraordinary strike and that it is different from the others. The only difference of any substance that he could show between this strike and others is that this one has been directed against small business. I certainly say, as I said earlier, that small business should be preserved and developed, but that is obviously a different question from the one we have before us now.

In the light of the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems or any other report, if we are to change the way in which unions, small business or industrial relations operate in this country, let us debate it at a proper hour. Do not let us debate it in the context of a motion, a context in which we really cannot come to any proper conclusions because an attack is being made on a particular body, a context which produces a lot of heat and very little understanding. Let us debate those issues calmly. As I understand it, Senator Lewis is about to do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating that the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The actions of those militant unionists whose defiance of decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission may force the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd into closing its operations in Australia, and the necessity for the Government to take urgent action to have the dispute resolved.

I was quite staggered to hear Senator Robert Ray and Senator Cooney, both from Victoria, actually defending the union in this debate. I know that they have difficulties with the trade union movement because of the love affair currently being conducted between the Australian Labor Party and that movement, but I also know that both those honourable senators have professed in the past to be opposed to militant trade union action of the very type that is involved in this matter. Yet here they have publicly put on the record their defence of this militant union for its behaviour in this dispute. The interesting thing about that is that the behaviour of this union-I will be interested to hear what Senator Elstob has to say about this-is quite outside the Government's own prices and incomes accord. Of course, we know that it is contrary to the determination of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission but, even if the Government were to ignore that fact, the truth of the matter is that what this union is doing is quite outside the Government's own prices and incomes accord, which I have said all along is a completely meaningless fraud. Even if one were to accept the Government senators' point of view in relation to the accord, here is a union acting outside the accord and Government senators are coming to that union's defence. That quite staggers me. I hope that when this matter is put to a vote they will call for a division so that their names can be recorded in the Senate Hansard as having supported the union in this matter.

Let me refer to something mentioned by Senator Cooney at the very end of his speech. He said that the Government had done very well in keeping down union disputation in recent years, thanks to the accord. Of course the Government has done very well in keeping down union disputation because as a result of the accord unionists and union officials know that they have been able to obtain salary rises for which there was absolutely no justification. There is no other way in which they could possibly have got those salary rises through the community at a time when the world and Australia were suffering a recession, when there was a drought in Australia and this economy was down on its knees. As a result of the accord union officials were able to push through industry wage rises to which they were clearly not entitled.

What has been the result of that? Clearly, there has been increased unemployment. I have to qualify that statement because, as a result of the recovery which has been brought about first and foremost by the Fraser wage pause, one of the greatest economic events to have happened in this country, as a result of Australia's recovery from the drought and as a result of the world recession recovery, this nation has started back into some sort of a recovery and unemployment should have fallen dramatically. But unemployment in this country has not fallen dramatically. It still stands at in excess of 600,000 people. Some 600,000 Australians are still unemployed, notwithstanding the recovery that has gone on all around the world. Australia is only staggering on, thanks to the Government's famous accord. Even worse, there are pockets in which in excess of 25 per cent of young people are unemployed. Honourable senators opposite should go to Newcastle and Wollongong and start facing up to those young people. If we are not careful, if we do not do something about giving these young people an opportunity of getting a job, we will have another Birmingham in this country. How are we going to give them that opportunity? By doing something about small business, by giving small business an opportunity to get up and do something for the nation.

What has happened here is that an extremely militant left wing union is squeezing to death a small Australian company called Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. Some people seem to think, because of its name, that it is a United States company, but that is not true. The family happens to be of Austrian parentage, but that is not relevant. They have been in Australia and established in Victoria for over 40 years. Dollar Sweets is a small Australian business employing 27 people. That business is being choked to death by a union which is acting outsite the prices and incomes accord by demanding something the Government says it is not entitled to get. It is acting contrary to a determination of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Because this union was in so much trouble, being totally outside all the Australian Council of Trade Union principles, or whatever they might be called, it has tried to slide. As I said to Senator Cooney, it has tried to say: `Now the employer is employing scabs and that gives us an opportunity to get back within the accord'. The truth of the matter, the fundamental principle here, is that this union made a demand for a 36-hour week and is trying to bankrupt this company, forcing it into either closing down its operation in Australia or granting a 36-hour week by militant action.

The people on the other side of the chamber keep saying to Opposition senators that we are union bashers. Let me tell them right here and now that I am not involved in bashing the union. I am bashing the Australian Labor Party, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), his Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, and this Government. That is what I am involved in. Let me elaborate on those matters. This Government has done nothing to help Dollar Sweets. Mr Stauder, the Managing Director of this company, sent a telegram to the Prime Minister saying:
Urgently seeking your intervention in current industrial disputes plaguing our company . . .

The telegram went on at some length. What has happened? Mr Hawke has replied with a pathetic sort of nonsense, saying: `Yes, we understand your terrible burden. We will look at it and see whether there is anything we can do.' But the Government is not doing anything. As long ago as 24 July 1985 Mr Hawke sent a telegram in which he said:

My Government strongly supports the wage fixing principles and is concerned that the claim by the Federated Confectioners Association of Australia be dealt with in accordance with those principles. In saying that I note that the principles do not provide for reductions in weekly hours of work below 38 hours.

Regarding your request for Federal assistance, I am aware that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has drawn this matter to the attention of the ACTU and has asked his Department to investigate the dispute. I will be taking a personal interest in the matter.
Well, that is lovely from him. That is really marvellous; the Prime Minister is going to take a personal interest in it. But what has he done? He has asked his Minister to refer it to the ACTU.

Let me just talk about the ACTU because I am concerned that it appears that a very wide sector of the community is worrying about the union movement. Let me quote from the editiorial of the Canberra Times of 10 September this year. The editorial states:

Grave-diggers can refuse to bury corpses to protect the jobs of coffin-makers; hospital employees can refuse to staff hospitals; meat workers can deprive an abattoir of a multi-million-dollar export contract; transport and maritime unions can cost the country coal and wheat sales; feather-bedding can render public utilities-postal services, grain-handling facilities, State power industries, rail and shipping services-uneconomic; transport and maritime unions can delay exports of coal and wheat; the trade-union movement can resist penal sanctions yet refuse to condone the deregistration of the Builders' Labourers' Federation, and individuals can be prevented from working because they refuse to join a union. And yet according to the unions' way of thinking, it is all a matter of image and public relations.

That Canberra Times editorial is absolutely devastating. I am concerned for the union movement. Even Australian Labour Party senators must realise that there is a declining morality within the trade union movement. This decline is very relevant to this Government. The truth is that there was a degree of morality in the trade union movement during the time of Mr Albert Monk. At that time there were agreements within the trade union movement and the employer organisations. This country was going down a decent path under Albert Monk. But what happened? A young fellow by the name of Hawke said to the extreme left wingers in the trade union movement: `If you elect me President of the ACTU I will ensure that the ACTU deprives itself of its power to control its own members'. That was one of the most significant powers that the ACTU was able to exercise over the trade union movement. I am sure that Senator Elstob, who is sitting on the other side of the Senate, knows that I am telling the truth. I can see that he knows that I am telling the truth when I say that the trade union movement was able to be kept under control by this power. That was the power that would have brought the union which is the subject of this debate under control. But, no, Mr Hawke promised the left wing unions that if they elected him to power he would get rid of that power; that he would in fact gut himself, just as the Government has with the accord. Mr Hawke won with the support of the left wing trade union movement, became the President of the ACTU, and took away the power that he had to control militant action by the trade union movement. Then, of course, he ultimately dumped the left wingers. They now absolutely hate him because ultimately he left them in the lurch. However, he still deprived the ACTU of the power which Mr Monk and his executive officers had been able to exercise for many years to keep unions, like this union, under control.

Mr Hawke is now the Prime Minister. Almost his very first action when he became Prime Minister was to introduce a thing called the accord in respect of which the Government gave up further powers which it might have had over its own employees. It undertook to enter into some special arrangement with the trade union movement whereby it said: `We will all be lovey-dovey and kissy kissy'. Of course, under such an arrangement no one will exercise any degree of control over anyone. The trade union movement will be able to step right outside the rule of law and behave in the same sort of militant fashion that it is behaving in this dispute. The result of all that is that when a union moves outside and behaves in the way this union is doing, this Government and the ACTU are powerless to take any action.

As I said before, the morality of the trade union movement of Australia has fallen completely since the time when Mr Hawke became President of the ACTU. The public of Australia clearly see that the trade union movement has to be brought under legislative control. The trade union movement is not regulating itself as it ought to be doing under ACTU principles. The trade union movement has stepped right outside the general expectations of the public of Australia. All it is concerned about is its image. In fact, this week it is discussing how to fix up its image with the people. When the trade union movement starts to show some degree of control over its members and some degree of sensibility and makes some contribution towards this nation and its economic future we will find that plenty of people from this side will be prepared to come to its defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has moved an urgency motion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The actions of those militant unionists whose defiance of decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission may force the Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd into closing its operations in Australia, and the necessity for the Government to take urgent action to have the dispute resolved.

All on the Liberal side of the Senate who have spoken in this debate have condemned the trade union movement for being behind this dispute. They have said that it is the bad element in the dispute. However, one has to bear in mind that before this dispute began 90 per cent of employers in the confectionery industry had given their employees a 36-hour week. They have already been given that right. I believe that the person to blame in this dispute is the chief executive officer and federal director of the Confectionery Manufacturers of Australia Ltd who agreed with the decision to grant a 36-hour week in all the other industries.

Incidentally, I am amazed at what Senator Siddons had to say because I considered that he had probably a better industrial relations brain than do some people in the Liberal Party. The amount of pressure on a union is astronomical when 90 per cent of firms grant their employees a 36-hour week and 10 per cent do not. The union is forced to implement measures to ensure that employees in that 10 per cent of firms also are granted a 36-hour week. Mr Mulcahy, the executive officer, must have agreed on behalf of the members of his association. The Confectionery Manufacturers of Australia said to the other companies `Yes, we will agree to a 36-hour week'. The Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd is one of the 10 per cent of companies in that industry which have not got a 36-hour week, so what position did that leave the union in? What position did it leave Dollar Sweets in? If the company did not attend the meetings-and surely there must have been meetings for the Association to agree to a 36-hour week in that industry-do not tell me that that was because it was left out, that it was negligent or that it did not know what was going on. Maybe the confectionery industry wants to destroy the Dollar Sweets company. I do not know. I am not in that industry.

I do know that the majority of disputes in industry are caused through either mismanagement or because people in the union movement have not had enough training. The basis of all disputes is one of those things. I admit from the trade union side that years ago many disputes were brought about by ignorance. Since the Trade Union Training Authority, the Clyde Cameron College, has come into being, union officials and delegates at the shop floor level have improved. They are better trained and consequently there have been fewer industrial disputes. That has not applied to the employers. This is a classic case of the employers not knowing what is going on. Why did the employers in this industry give workers in 90 per cent of the industry a 36-hour week? I do not know how that came about. Honourable senators opposite should be directing their venom at the person who decided that. They may be justified in doing that. It is too late just to blame the union. The pressure is on the union to get the 36-hour week for the other 10 per cent in the industry. What have the management people in the confectionery industry been doing? They are now screaming when 90 per cent of the industry has got the 36-hour week.

I agree that this claim is outside the national wage guidelines and I agree that it is wrong. However, I do not know how 90 per cent of the industry gained the 36-hour week. That is why the trouble arose. It is no good honourable senators opposite shaking their heads. One has to be realistic in industrial relations. The Hawke Government has gone out of its way in the area of industrial relations. Senator Lewis said that the accord just came about. It did not just come about-many people in the Australian Labor Party went out and talked to unionists, to sub-branches of unions and to other people to get that accord in place. It was not easy. It is not easy to keep it in place. I am certain it will be kept in place but it is jolly hard work.

The accord has given this country a great boost. The country was going downhill. I was alarmed at conditions in this country. We had high unemployment and inflation and everything was going wrong. Any Australian would have been disturbed about what was going on. It is slowly coming back together but only through continual consultation, not just between a few people but between many people-possibly more people than honourable senators realise. For the Opposition to bring up one dispute like this does not benefit better industrial relations or profits-things which are so essential to get people back to work. I think Senator Lewis said that some years ago I said that there has to be an improvement in profits. I was a trade unionist, but I understand that without profits we cannot employ the people of this country. We have to give the investors a reasonable return. But, why blame the trade union movement in this instance?

I blame this dispute on bad management. There should be a college for business leaders. The college for trade unionists has improved the working class-it has improved the representations that the unions have made. The Clyde Cameron College has made a great improvement. I do not think anyone can deny that. It is very important now to train foremen and employers-all levels of management-in all areas of industrial relations. That will come about only when we have better employers and when they understand industrial relations issues.

I was rather amazed at the comments of Senator Siddons. I have taken the trouble to look at the industry he controls. He is not one of those people who sit in an ivory tower and never talk to the workers. He does, and I give him great credit for that. However, what position would his industry, the metal trades industry, be in if it gave 90 per cent of its workers a 36-hour week and a $50 increase? What position would he or other people in that industry then be in? The unions would have to take on Senator Siddons because they would be left with no other course of action. When everyone else is getting it, you have to be in it. That is the reality of the situation.

As I have said, maybe there is a move by international sweet companies in this country. Maybe there is a move to remove the Dollar Sweets company from the industry. I do not know. I have not looked at the matter but I am very suspicious about it. The trade union movement should not be blamed in this instance because it is not its fault. The union has been forced into this position because the members of the union have forced it into it. It is just not good enough for honourable senators opposite to blame the union. A lot of discredit and criticism should be aimed at the employer groups. I do not think it did Senator Short any good in saying that the dispute was all the union's fault. It is not. It is out of the union's hands. I think Senator Short should have looked at the situtation before he proposed his motion today.

We live in a democratic country. What can this Government do? Can the Government force people to do things? Can it bring out the military or the police force? It cannot do so. It has to work through the industrial courts. It has to accept the situation that exists. There is no other way. It has to work within democracy. Democracy is very fragile. Many senators on the other side would like to get the big stick out and bring in more legislation. I assure honourable senators opposite that that is not the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the rebel unions.

—In any organisation, whether it be an employer organisation or a worker organisation, there will always be rebels. There will always be such people in the honourable senator's Party or mine. In any organisation there will be people who will disagree. That is not unusual and it is not unhealthy. However, I would be very worried if people insisted on dealing with these measures by unfair methods. We must work within the courts and we must try to encourage people. In this case the union had no alternative but to apply the pressure that it did. It is not a situation of its making. It is now too late. Sweet manufacturers long ago should have made up their minds that they would resist the 36-hour week before 90 per cent of their industry was working it. That is where the trouble has arisen. It is not the unions' making; it is the employers. We cannot blame worker organisations for the industry's mismanagement. That is how this has come about.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe Senator Short has not proved that this Government has been negligent in any shape or form. We have tried and we will keep on trying to improve industrial relations and to keep industrial relations agreements. I know that this country will go from strength to strength. I know that we will be able to reduce unemployment and bring inflation and interest rates down to achieve all those things beneficial to the nation. We will not be able to do so as individuals; it will be done collectively. There is still a lot of work to be done. I do not think that matters such as this urgency motion play any meaningful role. I think such motion should be very well thought out before they are moved in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate and exercising my right of reply in this urgency debate, I do not want to take up the Senate's time unduly but there are a couple of issues which I think should be raised. Firstly, I think the contribution to the debate this afternoon by honourable senators on the Government side has been very disappointing indeed. The reason those honourable senators' contributions have been disappointing is that they have walked around the issue which is the subject of this motion. This motion does not concern industrial relations generally; nor does it concern economic policies or the like, as Senator Robert Ray, in particular, tried to suggest. He really did not address his remarks to this dispute. Senator Cooney and Senator Elstob did address the matter a little more directly but they were still a long way away from debating the issues of this urgency motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the urgency motion refers to two issues. The first issue concerns the action by militant unionists involved in the dispute concerning Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd. The rights or wrongs of the dispute itself are really not at issue in this debate, although I would take great exception to the proposition by Government speakers, particularly Senator Elstob, that the dispute arose as a result of something that the employers had done. Nothing could be further from the truth. The dispute has arisen because a rogue union is trying to crush a small company acting in accordance with the rulings of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the wage fixation guidelines of that Commission. Indeed, the company is acting under the principles of the prices and incomes accord. Therefore, we have had a situation today in which Government speakers tried to diffuse an issue concerning a union acting in complete defiance of the Government's own accord, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Australian Council of Trade Unions itself. Those are the facts which ought to have been debated this afternoon.

Senator Elstob talked about democracy and said that we have to preserve our democratic institutions. I agree with him completely. That, too, is largely what this debate is about. The actions of the unions in relation to the Dollar Sweets company could not be more undemocratic and alien to the democratic standards and principles by which the overwhelming majority of Australians live and which, perhaps, represent the most important part of being Australian. Those values are under threat in this dispute.

Secondly, the Government's action in trying to resolve this dispute was hedged about by Government speakers. I can only repeat what I said during the debate: Senator Button, when asked by me about this issue on 22 August, by which stage the dispute had been running for two months, knew nothing about it. He is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) was advised the same day, or the day after, the telephone and telex connections were sabotaged at the Dollar Sweets company. That was on 17 August. The Minister did not even bother to reply to the request for assistance by the company. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) have said-I accept this-that they support the company management. However, they have done nothing at all to further that support, which really is just paper support. So the story goes on.

A few other things were said during the debate, particularly by Senator Elstob, which need some correction on the public record. I am advised that Mr Mulcahy, the Chief Executive Officer of the Confectionery Manufacturers Association of Australia, has never agreed to the 36-hour a week claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is in that Association.

—I know he is in that Association. However, the confectionery manufacturers were hopelessly crushed by the union movement. This is so, even of the bigger companies. I am not sure whether Senator Elstob is aware that there were 93 strikes at the Cadbury company's plant alone before an agreement on a 36-hour week was reached. The agreement on a 36-hour week came only because of crushing union pressure on a company which was employing many people and which, if it had not bowed to that union pressure after 93 strikes, would have had to close its doors. Exactly the same principle applies in the Dollar Sweets case. Exactly the same principle applies to all those other companies which have been involved in the 36-hour a week exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: The companies which granted the 36-hour week claim did so also before the prices and income accord was arrived at. That is the point I make to Senator Elstob. What the union involved in the Dollar Sweets case is now going for is contrary to the accord which his government praises so highly. The point Senator Elstob made was quite irrelevant. For the Dollar Sweets company to accede to the union demand in this case would be to put it in contravention of the wage fixing principles of this nation, principles from which Senator Elstob, his Government and his Party derive such satisfaction. These are principles about which one could have very grave doubts in regard to their virtue and value. Nevertheless they are principles. TALK.START.PARA: —That Association was at fault.

The Association is supporting a small member company because that small member company-namely, the Dollar Sweets company-is being crushed by one of the most militant left wing unions. That left wing union is being supported, assisted and advised by another, perhaps the most, militant left wing union, in Australia, namely, the Food Preservers Union of Australia. No wonder it called on the resources of the employer body of which it is a member, along with 128 other companies, most of which are small and medium size businesses. I welcome the recognition of the importance of Australia's trade with China and its future prospects because of its high growth potential. Historians will record the decision by the Chinese to open up their economy more to the outside world as one of the major economic events of this century. However, I think that few people in this country realise that significant trade between our two countries has existed for decades, principally in wheat, wool and some other commodities. We have to acknowledge that trading with China will never be easy. It will be frustrating. It will be a high risk. It will be subject to peaks and troughs from year to year as China grapples with the need to acquire foreign exchange and as it only slowly throws off the shackles of being a programmed society.

I believe that government and industry must work hand in glove, not as joint venturers, but as industry taking the risks and as government offering advice in opening up new doors to the opportunities that exist in China. The Australian Ambassador to China, Denis Argall, said recently that Australian companies must take the bit by the teeth, make the front end investment required, and get into the China market. Apart from the opportunities provided by our valuable steel resources, the opening up of China's economy provides a not to be missed opportunity, particularly for our rural sector, because of China's planned rural reforms. Also, China is interested in the smaller entrepreneurial Australian companies which are keen to invest in China.

Briefly, I should like to draw to the Senate's attention some of the initiatives that have been taken by Tasmanian businesses, and by our State Government headed by Robin Gray, in meeting this challenging opportunity. A recent trade mission headed by the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry, accompanied by a number of businessmen, was highly successful. The Chinese expressed their interest in a wide variety of venture projects. A number of Chinese have visited our State and have already placed orders. A significant rural company, Websters Ltd, has four people working with the Chinese in developing China's rural industries.

In October, the first shipment of Tasmanian animals to three Chinese provinces will begin. The Chinese are very enthusiastic about the role Tasmania can play because we are a natural quarantine station for Australia. In fact, Websters has signed a $3m deal with the Zhejiang Province in China. China recognises Tasmania's leadership in dairy farming and processing. It is keen to purchase our expertise and product development. Websters anticipates that it will be involved in another project based on our grassland farming techniques. In such a venture, this Tasmanian company could be supplying China with seed, agricultural and dairy equipment, and livestock, as well as communicating our technical expertise to their farmers. Another company, United Milk, has recently signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a dairy program in Tasmania. It expects to sell equipment, milk powder and processing technology.

One of our foremost building organisations, Trinity Projects Pty Ltd, was also represented on the trade visit to China. It has been invited to make submissions to the Chinese Government as joint venturers in projects, possibly for hotels in cities that have been recently opened up for foreign investment. The Chinese anticipate that such joint venture projects will take place at a small business level rather than with government involvement. China is a wide open market for our technological skills. For example, in many areas of China concrete is still mixed by hand. Tasmanian businesses as well as our farmers can expect to earn significant export revenue. China wants these projects to be joint ventures. It has raised the possibility of the Tasmanian Development Authority acting as an agent for payments between the Chinese and Tasmanian importers and exporters. Tasmanians are very enthusiastic about the trading opportunities offered by China. By gaining a foothold in the developing Chinese commercial and rural markets, as well as in the rural base, Tasmanian companies could create many more employment opportunities, not only in China but also in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —This paper, Australia's Trade with China, is the text of a statement made by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) in the House of Representatives on 22 August. I am happy to follow Senator Watson, who has drawn attention to the fact that, while in this chamber there are many matters on which the various parties will divide, one matter on which we can unite is our bipartisan attitude to promoting Australia's best interests in developing a greater volume and diversity of trade with China. The paper before us is a statement issued by the Minister for Trade prior to his departure on a two-week visit to China on 25 August.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to note that this Government has followed in the wake of Gough Whitlam who, in 1972, as the Leader of the Opposition, took a specific initiative to open up the China market for Australia by personal contact. Our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has visited that country and Hu Yaobang, the Vice-President of the Communist Party of China, has visited Australia. The mission by the Trade Minister, Mr Dawkins, from 25 August to 3 September was to continue to develop at a personal level the contacts between our countries so that the trade in which we engage will flow from mutual understanding and support.

This Government has established the China action plan as the model for promoting trade between our countries. We have increased the number of representatives of the Australian Trade Commission in Beijing and in other provincial centres in China to provide a focus for Australian business and Chinese interests to develop a two-way trade. We have appointed, with the rank of Ambassador, a special trade representative to North Asia, Mr Paul Barratt, who has the task of guiding not only the opening of the China market but also the markets in Japan and Korea. The Department of Trade has sold out the first edition of its publication `How to Trade with China'. Such is the interest of Australian business that there was an immediate rush to acquire that document upon its release.

The important thing to know about Australia-China trade from the Australian side is that while China has pursued the policy recently of opening up to the West, it is the only significant new world market that has been opened in the last few years, and the only one likely to be. It is a market of one billion people. If there is just a small increase in the standard of living of those one billion people, countries such as Australia which are in the neighbourhood of that market can gear their industrial production to take advantage of that standard of living increase. They can find for us a whole new market, the like of which has not existed before.

China has set itself the goal of increasing by four times the gross output of its industry and agriculture between 1980 and the year 2000. It is also looking to quadruple the volume of foreign trade between 1980 and 2000. We see for ourselves a particular role in achieving part of that quadrupling of foreign trade. In fact, the performance of Australia in trade with China in the last year has been remarkable. In 1984-85 our exports to China increased by 73.4 per cent. For the first time we exceeded $1 billion in the total value of our exports. The actual figure was $1.056 billion. China improved from being our tenth most important market to our fifth most important market in the space of 12 months. The main component of our trade has been wheat, but that now stands at 29 per cent of the total value of trade with that country. That is a smaller percentage than before, although the volume of wheat traded with China is greater than before. The important aspect is that our trade is diversifying. We are now trading in a whole range of other commodities.

The main point I want to mention is the interest of my State of Western Australia in seeing that joint ventures, technical co-operation, and Chinese investment in Australian facilities are developed further. Western Australia is renegotiating the reopening of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's Kwinana steel works with iron ore supplied from the mine of Koolyanobbing to develop a pig iron market with China on a joint venture basis. CSR Ltd, through Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd, is seeking to negotiate an agreement to open a mine to supply the China market with iron ore from the Pilbara at Mt Channar. Both those negotiations are important and have been going for some time. They are negotiations we are confident can be successfully concluded.

—I commend the statement and the initiatives taken by this Government and previous governments in increasing trade with China. It is very important that Australia seek new markets in the light of continuing problems with the European Economic Community. The highly subsidised rural industries of the EEC make it very important that we move into a new area. I am pleased that Australia has expanded its trade representation in China. I compliment the Government on recommendation (iv) of the statement that the Department of Trade be given the necessary resources required to enable it to service effectively what may become one of Australia's major export markets. I think the potential for even more expansion is enormous. Of course, this is because the Australian Wool Corporation has really worked at it. It has been an aggressive marketing source in Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —I take pleasure in joining other senators in welcoming the statement of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) made last August prior to his visit to China. SPEECH.PARA: The matter of trade illustrates the way in which throughout the 1970s and 1980s successive Australian governments have built foundation upon foundation so that we now have a quite strong base for considerable expansion in Australia-China trade in the future. The recognition of China, which I as a Liberal advocated in the late 1960s and early 1970s, was brought about by the new Labor Government in 1973. The foundations for better understanding were laid when the first Ambassador, Dr Fitzgerald, went from Australia to Beijing. The achievements of the Whitlam Government became a foundation for the very real enhancement of our relations during the Fraser Government period. Mr Fraser, as Prime Minister, visited China very successfully and he welcomed senior Ministers of the Chinese Government to Australia. On hearing Senator Pat Giles's report on the achievements of the Australian Government and the development of the status of women in this country over the last decade and her report on the Office of the Status of Women and the preferred way of this Government in developing policies for women, a number of the other delegates were interested to seek out the Australian delegation for further elaboration and clarification. In some ways the office, with those objectives, has not been caught up in the immediate day to day considerations of all those issues, but has maintained for itself a slightly distant and, therefore, an overview role. People were very interested to discover that and I certainly find it a preferred option or way of proceeding.

In particular this report highlights that on Budget night, 20 August 1984, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tabled a document entitled the `Womens Budget Program'. TALK.START.PARA: —When this report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations was tabled I made some remarks about it and sought leave to continue my remarks at a later stage. Since that time the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has written to me in my capacity as Chairman of the Finance and Government Operations Committee, advising me of the Government's response to that report. As the Bill concerned-the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985-is listed for debate in the very near future, I thought it would be appropriate if I reported to the Senate the results of the Minister's letter to the Committee. Senator Walsh's letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to advise you that the Government had decided to accept the substance of three of the four amendments to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 that were recommended in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations tabled on 15 May 1985. I intend to move amendments to that effect.

The amendments accepted by the Government further enhance the accountability of the Trust to the Parliament and to the contributors to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. The amendments I will be moving are intended to:

ensure that the Trust's annual report and any interim report will include particulars of any statements of Government policy provided by the Minister to the Trust during the year, the consideration given by the Trust to the policy and the action, if any, taken (Recommendation 1 of the Standing Committee);

require the ACTU to nominate persons for appointment to the Trust only from those persons whose names have been submitted to the ACTU by relevant industrial organisations (Recommendation 2 of the Standing Committee); and
require a copy of any interim report made by the Trust, together with interim financial statements, to be tabled in the Parliament (Recommendation 4 of the Standing Committee).
For drafting reasons, the precise wording and positioning in the Bill of the additional provisions differ somewhat from the recommendations of the Standing Committee but their substance is retained.

The Government has not, however, accepted the Committee's Recommendation 3 which seeks to provide that one or the other of the principal members of the Trust or the part-time government nominee is to have special qualifications in investment matters.

The proposed structure of the enlarged Trust, and the duties and responsibilities imposed upon it under the legislation, indicate the need for it to have members with broad qualifications, not necessarily related solely to investment. These duties and responsibilities involve not only the investment of the Superannuation Fund, but also the exercise of prudential controls, determination of policy and liaison with relevant industrial organisations as well as the staffing, control and oversight of the office of the Trust. In short, management of the Superannuation Fund goes well beyond investment of the Fund.

You remarked when tabling the Standing Committee's report on the Bill that the matters recommended for inclusion in the Bill by the Standing Committee would undoubtedly happen in practice anyway. The process of selection of Trust members, whether conducted to meet the requirements of the Minister or relevant industrial organisations as co-ordinated by the ACTU, would certainly have due regard to financial and investment expertise among the many qualities required of members of the Trust. The legislative specification of a requirement for such expertise would not only be redundant but would focus concern on only one aspect of the necessary qualifications, whether required of the principal member or the part-time government nominee, perhaps to the detriment of other, equally important concerns.

The fifth recommendation of the Standing Committee is to the effect that the Government immediately seek the current opinion of the Attorney-General on the matter of the legal liability of Trust members and Trust staff and introduce an appropriate amendment to the Act defining that liability. The Government has not put aside the matter of legal liability which was first raised in the Monaghan Report and later canvassed in the Joint Working Party Report, both of which have been tabled in Parliament.

Liability, however, raises a number of issues of considerable legal complexity. Resolution of these issues is being pursued with the Attorney-General's Department as expeditiously as possible so that consideration can be given to the matter and, if necessary, appropriate provisions included in the Superannuation Act 1976 when next it is amended.

I also understand that there is some concern as to the impact of the changes to sub-section 159 (2) of the Act on the Northern Territory. The amendments proposed are not specifically directed at, or occasioned by, the Government's negotiations with the Northern Territory on its employer superannuation liability.

The new sub-section 159 (2) of the Act proposed in paragraph 24 (1) (g) of the Bill was included so that the authorities, such as the ABC, CSIRO, etc, that prior to 1 July 1981, were treated as if exempt from making employer superannuation payments, could be relieved of the pre-1981 liability.

As the Superannuation Act 1976 now stands the Northern Territory of Australia, which became an approved authority for the purposes of that Act on 1 July 1978, has a legal obligation to pay to the Commonwealth that part of the benefits paid under the Act that has accrued in respect of service by its staff since 1 July 1978.

The Government is prepared to waive the liability of the Northern Territory that accrued in respect of service between 1 July 1978 and 30 June 1984. This liability could not legally be waived under the current legislation. it would, however, be possible to waive it under the new sub-section 159 (2).

The intention of the Government is that the Northern Territory and its authorities reimburse the Commonwealth for their share of the pensions and other benefits paid under the Commonwealth Scheme on the ``emerging cost'' basis, ie the Territory would reimburse the Commonwealth only as benefits were actually paid to the Territory's former employees from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. Under this basis, payments to the Commonwealth will commence at a very low level and increase over time, giving the Northern Territory ample time to be able to finance the cost of its share of the benefits.

The current legislation enables an authority to enter into an arrangement with the Minister for Finance to make an alternative series of payments to the Commonwealth to discharge its superannuation liabilities. The alternative adopted is known as the ``pay-as-you-go'' basis and the payments made assume funding of benefits as they accrue. Most authorities voluntarily adopt the ``pay-as-you-go'' basis of reimbursing the Commonwealth.

Paragraph 24(1) (g) of the Bill also proposes a new sub-section of the Act, 159(2D), that retains this provision but also provides that the Minister for Finance may direct that an authority shall make payments on the ``pay-as-you-go'' basis.

This new provision is a reserve power that would be used only where an authority had adopted the ``emerging cost'' basis for payment and was not, in the opinion of the Minister, making adequate provision to meet the future costs under that basis. Where ``emerging cost'' authorities are making adequate provision, or their ability to pay is not in doubt, as is the case with the Northern Territory, there would be no reason to invoke the reserve power.

As indicated above, the proposed amendments to sub-section 159(2) are not directed specifically at the Northern Territory. Therefore, whilst the proposed amendments could have application to the Northern Territory, I do not consider that the Bill could be seen as anticipating the Senate Committee's report.

I have read that letter from the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, into the record because of the importance of the issue and also because of the fact that this morning the Finance and Government Operations Committee held a further hearing on the Northern Territory superannuation matter. Thus it is particularly relevant for the Senate to be aware of the Minister's response to the Bill. I urge those who are concerned about some provisions of the Bill to accept the fact that the Minister has adopted the main aspects of concern that the Committee raised and, therefore, there should be no further problem about the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
